content.text: Now that you understand how functions work, it is important to learn how variables act inside and outside of functions.
content.html: Now that you understand how functions work, it is important to learn how variables act inside and outside of functions.

content.text: In C, variables are only accessible inside the region they are created. This is called scope .
content.html: In C, variables are only accessible inside the region they are created. This is called scope.

content.text: A variable created inside a function belongs to the local scope of that function, and can only be used inside that function:
content.html: A variable created inside a function belongs to the local scope of that function, and can only be used inside that function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Local variable that belongs to myFunction

syntax_highlighting.text: // Local variable that belongs to myFunction

content.code_html:
void myFunction() {
  // Local variable that belongs to myFunction
  int x = 5;

  // Print the variable x
  printf("%d", x);
}

int main() {
  myFunction();
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Local variable that belongs to myFunction

content.text: A local variable cannot be used outside the function it belongs to.
content.html: A local variable cannot be used outside the function it belongs to.

content.text: A variable created outside of a function, is called a global variable and belongs to the global scope .
content.html: A variable created outside of a function, is called a global variable and belongs to the global scope.

content.text: Global variables are available from within any scope, global and local:
content.html: Global variables are available from within any scope, global and local:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // We can also use x here

syntax_highlighting.text: // We can also use x here

content.code_html:
// Global variable x
int x = 5;

void myFunction() {
  // We can use x here
  printf("%d", x);
}

int main() {
  myFunction();

  // We can also use x here
  printf("%d", x);
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // We can also use x here

content.text: If you operate with the same variable name inside and outside of a function, C will treat them as two separate variables; One available in the global scope (outside the function) and one available in the local scope (inside the function):
content.html: If you operate with the same variable name inside and outside of a function, C will treat them as two separate variables; One available in the global scope (outside the function) and one available in the local scope (inside the function):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Local 
  variable with the same name as the global variable (x)
// Refers to the local variable x
// Refers to the global variable x

content.code_html:
// Global variable x
int x = 5;

void myFunction() {
  // Local variable with the same name as the global variable (x)
  int x = 22;
  printf("%d\n", x); // Refers to the local variable x
}

int main() {
  myFunction();

  printf("%d\n", x); // Refers to the global variable x
  return 0;
}

content.text: However, you should avoid using the same variable name for both globally and locally variables as it can lead to errors and confusion.
content.html: However, you should avoid using the same variable name for both globally and locally variables as it can lead to errors and confusion.

content.text: In general, you should be careful with global variables, since they can be accessed and modified from any function:
content.html: In general, you should be careful with global variables, since they can be accessed and modified from any function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Increment the value of x by 1 and print it

// The value of 
    x is now 6 (no longer 5)

content.code_html:
// Global variable
int x = 5;

void myFunction() {
  printf("%d\n", ++x); // Increment the value of x by 1 and print it
}

int main() {
  myFunction();

  printf("%d\n", x); // Print the global variable x
  return 0;
}

// The value of x is now 6 (no longer 5)

content.text: To sum up, use local variables (with good variable names) as much as you can. This will make your code easier to maintain and better to understand. However, you may find global variables when working on existing C programs or while collaborating with others. Therefore, it is good to understand how the scope works and how to use it effectively to make sure your code is clear and functional.
